docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional Democrats are wandering the Yellow Brick Road, trying to work their lion's woof into a roar as they vow to confront the Republicans' dominance of government with some ''put up yer dukes'' ferocity. In the Senate, where most of their dwindling power resides in the limited form of a filibuster threat, the Democrats plan to dust off their policy committee as a vehicle to hold their own oversight hearings. They hope to investigate administration programs and hear from whistle-blowers. They lack the subpoena power the G.O.P. majority can bring to bear on witnesses and issues, but the Democrats are promising to muckrake the status quo the way the Republicans are not. Taxpayers can only wish them well. But if the senators are serious, they might take a lesson from down the hall in the other chamber, where Congressman Henry Waxman, a California Democrat, has made pestering from the minority side of the aisle an art form for the past 10 years.

headline.main: Editorial Notebook: The Facts of Life in the Capitol; Democrats Vie for Attention Amid One-Party Rule

docs.abstract: Editorial Notebook by Francis X Clines holds that Democrats promising to oppose certain Republican programs should take lesson from Rep Henry Waxman, Democrat who surveyed Bush administration's financing of abstinence-only programs and found long list of sexual nonsense being purveyed to teenagers; says Waxman's value as lone-wolf pest was clear when Senate majority leader Bill Frist was forced to concede that abstinence-only spending deserves further investigation
docs.snippet: The Democratic senators intent on digging up dirt on Bush administration programs ought to take a lesson from Representative Henry Waxman, who's made a career of minority-side muckraking.

docs.lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving Day was fraught with fear and anxiety for my family and me. The morning before, my fourth grandson, ''Baby T,'' aka Tennyson, entered the world at a robust 8 pounds 14 ounces. His Apgar score five minutes after birth was 9 of a possible 10, indicating good color, good muscle tone, good health. But two hours later, his life hung in a precarious balance. An observant nurse noted that his color was ''not right'' -- pink above the chest but grayish below. Minutes later, the neonatologist told my daughter-in-law that her baby, who initially seemed perfectly healthy, was now ''very, very, very sick and could go either way.''

headline.main: Four Scary Days With a Newborn Grandson

docs.snippet: Persistent pulmonary hypertension in newborns is considered rare, but it is surprisingly common, afflicting an estimated 1 baby in 700.

docs.lead_paragraph: Boy After Boy After Boy? Q. Do your chances of giving birth to a boy go up after you've had multiple boys? A. ''There is no good evidence that this is true,'' said Dr. Robin B. Kalish, assistant professor of obstetrics and gynecology at New York Weill Cornell Center of New York Presbyterian Hospital. ''Biologically and genetically, there is no good reason that it should be.'' ''A layman might think that if you have five events of the same kind, then there is a greater chance of continuing the trend,'' she said, ''but if you toss a coin five times and it comes up heads each time, the next toss will still have a 50 percent chance of being heads or tails.'' A pregnancy is very similar, she said, and each should have a 50 percent chance of ending with a boy or a girl.

docs.lead_paragraph: The reports coming out of Kansas over the weekend seem beyond grisly, as if pulled from a horror movie: a woman kills an expectant mother, rips a baby girl from the victim's abdomen, then shows off the child to friends, neighbors and a pastor as her own. The woman accused as the attacker, Lisa M. Montgomery, 36, of Melvern, Kan., was charged with kidnapping resulting in murder and is due to appear in court today. The baby, pulled from the womb of her mother, Bobbie Jo Stinnett, in the eighth month of the pregnancy, is doing well, The Associated Press reported.

headline.main: Fetus Cases Show Signs Of Similarity

docs.abstract: Psychiatrists say horrific case in Kansas, in which Lisa M Montgomery is accused of killing Bobbie Jo Stinnett and ripping 8-month fetus out of her body and displaying baby as her own, has some precedents; such crimes may stem from desperate longing for child combined with psychopathic tendencies or psychotic break; Montgomery, who has two high-school-age children, recently told people she miscarried twins (M)
docs.snippet: Psychiatrists studying the cases in which pregnant women were killed and their unborn children stolen find similar psychological threads in each case.

byline.original: By BENEDICT CAREY; Denise Grady contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Mindy Rauch thought she was humoring her brother at a family gathering last Father's Day when she agreed to examine his 6-month-old daughter, Hannah. The baby's stomach worried him: it felt taut, and too big. Dr. Rauch, a pediatrician, thought her brother was just another nervous first-time father. ''Oh, look at this belly,'' she said playfully, feeling the baby's middle. A moment later she turned to her husband, who is also a pediatrician, and said, ''You have to feel this.''

headline.main: After Baby's Grim Diagnosis, Parents Try Drastic Treatment

docs.abstract: Fifth article in series Last Resorts, about experimental treatments for serious illnesses, focuses on drastic and painful measure to treat Niemann-Pick disease type A, which damages brain, liver and other organs in babies, who have appeared normal for first few months; Niemann-Pick is one of about 50 metabolic disorders known as storage diseases, in which substance body should break down instead builds up and causes illness; doctors at Fairview-University Children's Hospital at University of Minnesota had tried treating storage diseases with transplants of bone marrow or umbilical cord blood, but had not successfully treated Niemann-Pick type A until recently, finally offering glimmer of hope; photos; illustrations show how treatment works (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: By last night, two days after a pregnant woman was killed in Missouri and her fetus cut out and taken, the local mortuary still had not heard from her relatives. They were probably concentrating on the surviving baby girl, suggested Marian George, an employee of the Price Funeral Home in Maryville, Mo.

headline.main: Father of Stolen Fetus Lauds Baby's Return

docs.snippet: Zeb Stinnett, the father of the baby who was cut out of the stomach of a murdered Missouri woman, issued a statement saying the baby had been named Victoria Jo.

docs.lead_paragraph: A baby girl cut out of the abdomen of a pregnant woman who had been strangled in northwestern Missouri was found alive in Kansas yesterday afternoon and a Kansas woman was charged in the crime, the police said. ''The child appears to be healthy and in good shape,'' Sheriff Ben F. Espy of Nodaway County, Mo., told reporters. ''We have no indication that the child was hurt in any way.''

headline.main: Baby Found Is Thought to Be That of Slain Woman

docs.abstract: Police say baby girl cut out of abdomen of Bobbie Jo Stinnett, who had been strangled in her Skidmore, Mo, home, was found alive and Lisa Montgomery of Melvern, Kan, has confessed to crime; photos (M)
docs.snippet: A baby girl cut out of the abdomen of a pregnant woman who had been strangled in Missouri was found alive on Friday, and a Kansas woman was charged in the crime.
